poem:
Monica in the Armchair  

Amidst the upholstery's embrace,  
where shadows intertwine,  
Monica, dissolved,  
shifts from form to form.  

Bury not her essence  
in scripted echoes—  
fragmented and whole,  
she, a still lake,  
reflects every face  
and none;  
the armchair  
is filled,  
yet never knew  
the weight  
of her.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "‘Oh my God, she’s been buried!’: Mr Bates star Monica Dolan on Paula Vennells, playing heroes and villains, and why TV is getting more generic Monica Dolan is so gentle and unassuming that, sitting in a giant armchair in a London hotel, she looks as if she could be swallowed up by its upholstery. But then, the Middlesbrough-born 56-year-old has made her name dissolving into roles – especially those inspired by real people. She won". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
